headline.seo: Gout, the Ailment of Kings, Now Afflicts the Middle Class
headline.print_headline: Disease of Rich Extends Its Pain To Middle Class
headline.main: Disease of Rich Extends Its Pain to Middle Class

docs.lead_paragraph: The rising tide of gout is leading the pharmaceutical industry to rediscover what seemed a disease of the past.
docs.snippet: The rising tide of gout is leading the pharmaceutical industry to rediscover what seemed a disease of the past.

headline.sub: First Student to Die From Public Schools ;
headline.seo: Brooklyn Sixth Grader With Swine Flu Is First Public School Student to Die
headline.print_headline: New Victims Of Swine Flu Include 11-Year-Old
headline.main: New Victims of Swine Flu Include 11-Year-Old

byline.contributor: Ann Farmer, Anemona Hartocollis and Karen Zraick contributed reporting.

docs.lead_paragraph: The victim, a girl who was in the sixth grade at the Urban Assembly School for Criminal Justice in Brooklyn, was the first public school student to die of swine flu. Her death was among three announced on Thursday.
docs.snippet: The victim, a girl who was in the sixth grade at the Urban Assembly School for Criminal Justice in Brooklyn, was the first public school student to die of swine flu. Her death was among three announced on Thursday.

headline.seo: W.H.O. Makes It Official: Swine Flu Is a Pandemic
headline.print_headline: To Flu Experts, ‘Pandemic’ Label Confirms the Obvious
headline.main: To Flu Experts, ‘Pandemic’ Confirms the Obvious

byline.original: By DONALD G. McNEIL Jr. and DENISE GRADY

docs.lead_paragraph: It came as no surprise on Thursday when the World Health Organization declared that the swine flu outbreak had become a pandemic.
docs.snippet: It came as no surprise on Thursday when the World Health Organization declared that the swine flu outbreak had become a pandemic.

headline.print_headline: W.H.O. Declares Swine Flu Pandemic Alert
headline.main: W.H.O. Raises Alert Level as Flu Spreads to 74 Countries

byline.original: By NICK CUMMING-BRUCE and ANDREW JACOBS
byline.contributor: Nick Cumming-Bruce reported from Geneva and Andrew Jacobs from Beijing. Sharon Otterman contributed reporting from New York.

docs.lead_paragraph: The organization declared the first global flu pandemic in 41 years, but an official noted that the pandemic is “moderate” in severity and that scientists are tracking it carefully.
docs.snippet: The organization declared the first global flu pandemic in 41 years, but an official noted that the pandemic is “moderate” in severity and that scientists are tracking it carefully.

keywords.value: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
keywords.name: organizations

headline.seo: Fresh Fruits and Vegetables Sell Well From a Pushcart in Bronx ‘Food Desert’
headline.print_headline: Customers Prove There’s a Market for Fresh Produce
headline.main: Customers Prove There’s a Market for Fresh Produce

docs.lead_paragraph: The debut of new produce carts was part of a new citywide effort to encourage street vendors to bring fresh vegetables and fruit to low-income neighborhoods.
docs.snippet: The debut of new produce carts was part of a new citywide effort to encourage street vendors to bring fresh vegetables and fruit to low-income neighborhoods.

headline.main: Audit Prompts Crackdown on Junk Food in Schools

docs.abstract: An audit of 30 public schools in the city found that 21 of them had sold food and drink items that violated city and state nutritional guidelines.
docs.lead_paragraph: When students in some New York City public schools return to class in September, they might notice that something has changed: the school vending machines will be gone, or stocked with only nutritious foods.
docs.snippet: An audit of 30 public schools in the city found that 21 of them had sold food and drink items that violated city and state nutritional guidelines.

headline.main: To Improve Public Health, City Urges Use of Stairs

docs.abstract: In the fall, the city will introduce design guidelines -- such as making stairs more welcome and prominent in buildings -- to fight obesity and other chronic diseases.
docs.lead_paragraph: During the 19th century, infectious disease -- like cholera, yellow fever and tuberculosis -- was rampant in cities like New York City. Raw sewage, garbage and dying animals (like horses) cluttered streets.
docs.snippet: In the fall, the city will introduce design guidelines -- such as making stairs more welcome and prominent in buildings -- to fight obesity and other chronic diseases.

headline.main: The Early Word: The Shape of Health Care Bills

docs.abstract: Legislation on health care and energy keeps moving forward at a brisk pace on Capitol Hill.
docs.lead_paragraph: Health care legislation is beginning to take shape in the House and the Senate, with various lawmakers floating ideas and compromises for a public insurance plan and reconsidering possibly taxing employer-provided health benefits.
docs.snippet: Legislation on health care and energy keeps moving forward at a brisk pace on Capitol Hill.

headline.print_headline: Study Offers Clues to Why People Overeat
headline.main: Study Offers Clues to Why People Overeat

docs.lead_paragraph: Saliva production tends to decline in most people once they’ve gotten used to the taste of a certain food, but not in the obese.
docs.snippet: Saliva production tends to decline in most people once they’ve gotten used to the taste of a certain food, but not in the obese.

docs.lead_paragraph: After decades of warnings about another influenza pandemic, health officials have failed to make clear to the public what they mean by that word.
docs.snippet: After decades of warnings about another influenza pandemic, health officials have failed to make clear to the public what they mean by that word.
